facts.fact: Octopuses have three hearts, and their blood is blue due to the presence of copper-based hemocyanin, helping them survive in cold ocean environments.
Dolphins sleep with one eye open and half of their brain awake to stay alert for predators and maintain vital breathing.
Sharks have been around for over 400 million years, making them older than dinosaurs and some of the oldest living species on Earth.
Crows are highly intelligent and capable of recognizing human faces, using tools, and even solving complex puzzles for food rewards.
Male seahorses are unique in the animal kingdom because they carry and give birth to their offspring after females transfer eggs into their pouch.
Butterflies taste with their feet, which have sensory organs that allow them to detect the chemical composition of plants they land on.
African elephants have the largest brains of any land animal, and their exceptional memory helps them navigate vast territories and find water sources.
The axolotl, a type of salamander, can regenerate entire limbs, heart tissue, and even parts of its brain, making it a focus of scientific research.
Penguins can stay underwater for up to 20 minutes, using their streamlined bodies and powerful flippers to dive deep while hunting for fish.
A group of flamingos is called a 'flamboyance,' reflecting their striking pink color, which comes from carotenoids found in the algae and shrimp they eat.
